Fig 14 Review Development of tailored TiO2 mesocrystals for solar driven photocatalysis Peng Zhang Mamoru Fujitsuka Tetsuro Majima * The Institute of Scientific and Industrial Research (SANKEN), Osaka University, Mihogaoka 8-1, Ibaraki, Osaka 567-0047, Japan The Institute of Scientific and Industrial Research (SANKEN) Osaka University Mihogaoka 8-1 Osaka Ibaraki 567-0047 Japan * Corresponding author. Fax: +81 6 6879 8499. Ordered metal oxides superstructures have attracted much more attention in the fields of fuel generation and environmental purification owing to their unique physiochemical characteristics such as large surface area, fine pore structure, efficient electronic mobility, and good stability. Very recently, TiO2 mesocrystals (TMCs) having superstructures self-assembled by TiO2 nanoparticle building blocks, are of considerable interest in current research and application ranging from UV to visible light attributed to their efficient charge separation and superior photocatalytic activity. In this review, we describe the common procedures to prepare unique TMCs and overview of recent developments of TMCs during last 3years, especially the structure-related or electronic-effected mechanism in photocatalytic reaction. Further, we introduce the characterization and fundamental properties of modified TMCs by the means of single-particle fluorescence microscopy for unraveling the charge transport and photocatalytic properties of individual TMCs and time-resolved diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (TDR) for monitoring the charge transfer dynamics. Finally, various aspects on TMCs are discussed for the future developments of energy and environmental fields. Graphical abstract This mini review highlighted mesocrystals with higher crystallinity and distinctive orientation to gain an in-depth understanding of the efficient charge separation within appropriate morphologies and superior structure-induced photocatalytic activity for environmental remediation and energy conversion. Image, graphical abstract Keywords TiO2 Mesocrystal Photocatalyst Topotactic transformation Doping Charge separation Co-catalyst Electron flow 1 Introduction Over the past decades, the rapid depletion of fossil fuels and serious environmental pollution started to strongly affect the modern society, such as the air pollution, water pollution and even our healthy body as monitored by PM 2.5. With concerning the deficiency of human energy consumption and alleviating the environmental pollution, solar energy as the sustainable source is becoming the clean, cheap, and renewable energy to fulfill rising global demand in our life. In this case, semiconductor-based photocatalysis shows great potentials among the basic science, environmental purification, fuel generation, and so on [1–3]. With recent development of nanotechnology, research interests on the photocatalyst have been expanded to ultimate efficient mental oxide semiconductors with intriguing physiochemical property and exciting functions in photo (electro) catalysis. Due to the strong redox ability, high chemical stability, low toxicity, and abundant availability, titanium dioxide (TiO2) is becoming one of the most promising photocatalyst in the tremendous amount of research related to solar-to-chemical energy conversion such as environmental remediation, solar water splitting, CO2 photo reduction, and photovoltaic cells [4–7]. As the starting photocatalytic materials since 1972 [4], TiO2 still represents problems in wide spread applications of photovoltaics and photo (electronic) catalysis inevitably due to low quantum efficiency and wide band gap (3.0–3.2eV). With the viewpoint of significant improvement of the low quantum efficiency in photocatalysis, a series of TiO2 with good structure-performance relationship have been developed and studied [5]. Due to the existence of charge recombination at surface or inside volume (Fig. 1 a) [6], partial photogenerated carriers can spatially diffuse to surface to generate reactive species for subsequent oxidation/reduction processes. It was found the efficient charge separation may retard the fast charge recombination in reaction process to enhance the quantum efficiency. With the development of a new class of porous metal oxides materials ranging from catalysis to optoelectronics, energy storage, and conversion [7–12], anatase TMCs consisting of TiO2 nanocrystal building blocks show significant enhancement of the charge separation and excellent photocatalytic activity than TiO2 nanocrystals or commercial TiO2 [13]. It was clearly revealed that the long-range ordered mesocrystal superstructures significantly retard the recombination of electron-hole pairs due to the anisotropic electron flow along the interparticles [14]. In this case, the rapid and efficient collection of photogenerated electrons or holes on the catalytic sites (i.e., blue or green circle in Fig. 1(a) represents reduction or oxidation sites, respectively) from the dominated surface of TMC is much more important to optimize the composite systems with improvement in the reactive efficiency (Fig. 1a). It is noteworthy that many efforts have been attempted to study band gap engineering of TiO2 with visible-light-responding to resolve intrinsic wide band gap, i.e. electron injection from dyes and narrowing band gap by doping (Fig. 1b) [15,16]. To date, a variety of modifications are exploited to extend the optical response of TiO2 from UV to visible light region, such as the nonmetal doping/co-doping (N, S, C, F), metal deposition (Au, Cu, V, Cr), coupling with semiconductors (CdS, Bi2S3), defect engineering (Ti3+), and dye sensitization (Ru complex) [16,17]. It is worthy considering that for the large-scale preparation in practical application, the novel pyrolysis of titanium-compound containing dopants elements is proposed to be the ideal candidate for acquiring efficient doping system. The ammonium oxofluorotitanate (NH4TiOF3) is one of the fundamental titanium-compound to synthesize doped TiO2. It was already inferred that the anisotropic dissolution of NH4TiOF3 can be topochemically converted to TMCs, accompanying with N and F releasing [13]. The facile synthesis of doped TMCs with higher visible-light activity is a great of significance to introduce the dopant during the topotactic transformation, without affecting the nucleation and growth of TMCs [18,19]. In this minireview, we focus on the development of modified or doped TMCs with versatile applications in photocatalytic H2 evolution and organics degradation ranging from UV to visible light. Mostly, we summarize our contribution to resolve the problems of low photocatalytic efficiency and intrinsic wide bang gap of TiO2 after facilely improved with co-catalyst, tunable anisotropic crystal facet, and doping. Finally, we discuss the structure-related or electronic-effected mechanism to make deep understanding and wide application in the future research of solar energy conversion concentrated on mesocrystal materials. 2 Topotactic transformation for the preparation of TMCs The concept of mesocrystal, defined as a mesoscale assembly of nanoparticle building blocks, was first introduced by Cölfen in 2005 [8,20–25]. Such highly ordered superstructures with potentially tunable photoelectric properties, considered as the new class of crystalline materials compared with traditional single crystal or polycrystals, are actively pursued in current research topics ranging from catalysis to optoelectronics [9–12]. From this point, various metal oxides mesocrystals, such as TiO2 [26–35], ZnO [36–46], Fe2O3 [47–53], and CuO [54–56] have been published via different synthetic approaches when compared definition between classical mechanism of atom/ion-mediated growth and non-classical crystallization [7,8,21–25,53–57]. Among the metal oxides, TMCs with low cost and good chemical stability have attracted more attention to design and use in wide field of environmental and energy applications [58]. Originally, the anatase TMCs were obtained first from O'Brien group via the topotactic transformation of NH4TiOF3 crystals [26]. Based on this synthetic procedure, the layered and hollow TMCs were also successfully prepared with combination of hydrothermal treatments [24,32]. Very recently, Majima group significantly published anatase TMCs with dominant facets via topotactic transformation in 2012 [13]. Their improved one-step annealing process is just to obtain plate-like TMCs by annealing a thin layer of precursor solution containing TiF4, NH4F, and NH4NO3 on a silicon wafer. After evaporation of water at low temperature (<200°C), the nonporous intermediate NH4TiOF3 was first appearance followed the combination reactions from precursors of Ti4+, F−, NH4+, and H2O (Eq. (1)). During further gradual annealing in higher temperature (200–500°C), NH4TiOF3 is topotactically transformed into porous anatase TMCs with the dominant facets [59]. It indicates the gaps or pores are formed between nanoparticles due to nanocrystal diffusion and recrystallization during large amounts of N, H, and F atoms removal from the crystal lattice (Eqs. (2)–(6)). The phase stability of anatase was retained after annealing up to 800°C with inhibiting formation of rutile phase [29]. It is worthy noting that anatase TMCs with exposed facet are formed corresponding to single-crystal anatase along the [001] zone axis [59]. That is because the final product TMCs orientationally related to the starting material NH4TiOF3 have the same positions of Ti atoms and atomic arrangement with small lattice mismatch (0.02%) in the planes via topotactic transformation (Fig. 2 ) [59]. The surface area and pore volume of the synthesized TMCs were 63m2/g and 0.2m3/g, respectively, which is still two-fold smaller than other synthesized single crystal-like anatase TMCs [29,30]. The TMCs constructed with ordered alignment of anatase nanocrystal (40nm in size) have porous structure with pore diameters of several nanometers, leading to remarkably long-lived charges, higher photoconductivity and photocatalytic activity [13,14]. (1) Ti4+ +3F− +NH4+ +H2O ⇄ NH4TiOF3↓+2H+(< 200°C) [13] (2) NH4TiOF3 +H2O ⇄ TiO2↓+2HF+NH4F (∼200°C) [60] (3) NH4TiOF3⇄ HTiOF3↓+ NH3↑(∼200°C) [26] (4) 2HTiOF3⇄ 2TiOF2↓+2HF (300∼ 400°C) [26] (5) TiOF2 +H2O⇄ TiO2↓+2HF (400 ∼ 500°C) [26] (6) NH4F ⇄ HF↑+NH3↑(400 ∼ 600°C) [61] 3 Spatial charge separation on TMCs with efficient photocatalytic activity Rapid and efficient collection of multiple photogenerated charges of electrons (e−) and holes (h+) on the surficial sites to accompany the redox events and bond formation is of paramount importance in the entire reaction. The co-catalysts modifications of semiconductors strongly affect the structural characteristics and interfacial charge transfer dynamics with improvement in the photocatalytic efficiency. 3.1 Co-catalysts selective modification on TMCs Photocatalytic performances are strongly affected on the preparation and the electronic and morphological structures of the semiconductors and co-catalysts. It is necessary to design and understand the relationship between the structural characteristics and the interfacial charge transfer dynamics to optimize the efficient performance of water splitting in composite systems. The plate-like structure of TMCs, composed of aligned anatase TiO2 nanocrystals with dominant {001} facets, is beneficial for the migration of photogenerated e− between adjacent nanocrystals upon UV light irradiation (Fig. 3 ). Further to facilitate charge separation and photocatalytic water splitting, the selective photochemical deposition of cobalt phosphate (CoPi) [62,63], known as an efficient oxygen-evolving catalyst onto semiconductor materials such as ZnO [64], TiO2 [65,66], Fe2O3 [67–71], WO3 [72], and BiVO4 [73], and of platinum (Pt) nanoparticles, used as a co-catalyst for hydrogen evolution [10–12], are published [74]. The width and thickness of TMC structures are 2–10µm and 50–300nm, respectively. The holes (h+)-accepting Co species (CoII and CoIII) in CoPi with higher energy level than TMCs are located at basal facet. While, photogenerated e− migrate to the edges of TMC through the nanocrystal network and are eventually captured by Pt nanoparticles [14], inducing preferable deposition of Pt nanoparticles on the lateral surfaces of CoPi-TMC. Active CoIII/IV species in CoPi as well as TiO2 h+ can oxidize probe dye of 3′-p-aminophenyl fluoresce in (APF) and 3′-p-hydroxyphenyl fluorescein (HPF) to generate fluorescein as a fluorescent product via O-dearylation reaction. In the other word, h+ in the valence band (VB) of TiO2 can be transferred to the CoPi catalysts and deposited on the (001) facet upon UV light irradiation [65,66], and the e− in the conduction band (CB) of TiO2 is preferentially transferred to lamellar (101) facet to deposit Pt, eventually inhibiting the undesired charge recombination. This interesting finding was in accordance with the observation of fluorescent spot location of Au and Pt nanoparticles selectively photo deposited at the edges of {101} facets [14]. The anisotropic charge flow can promote the efficient charge separation and photocatalytic activity. 3.2 Synergetic composite of MoS2 on TMCs It is a facile method to grow mesocrystalline assemblies or layers on supporting materials through the topotactic transformation [75,76]. Recently, two-dimensional MoS2 nanosheets have been extensively investigated and considered as an alternative candidate for the replacement of Pt in efficient hydrogen evolution reaction (HER). With the viewpoint of increasing the number of active sites and overcoming the inherent restriction of poor electrical conductivity, the assembly of chemically exfoliated MoS2 nanosheets as co-catalysts onto external surfaces of TMCs was designed after mild impregnation (Fig. 4 ) [77]. With continuous sonication in the precursor solution, negatively charged MoS2 after chemical exfoliation can be adsorbed on positively charged TiO2 due to the electrostatic interaction. Finally, the MoS2/TMC heterostructures were obtained after annealing the suspension on silicon (Si) wafer. From the structure of MoS2/TMCs (Fig. 4 inset), it was found that the newly synthesized TMCs remain cubic-like morphologies and the majority of MoS2 nanosheets are uniformly attached onto the external surfaces, which are essential for anisotropic electron flow to achieve the improvement of the reactive efficiency with desired functionality. 3.3 Tunable anisotropic electron flow on specific facet-dominated TMC Anisotropic crystal engineering is an important strategy for tuning and optimizing material reactivities [78–82] from the crystallography and physicochemical performances of semiconductors [83–86]. Photocatalysts with specific exposed facets exhibit pronounced redox behaviors because of their abundant adsorption sites, efficient separation of photogenerated electrons and holes, and synergism [87–94]. Surface-structure control of the atomic configuration can induce anisotropic crystal growth because of the different surface energies (0.90J/m2 for the (001) facet, 0.53J/m2 for (100) facet, and 0.44J/m2 for (101) facet) [95]. It was found that the photocatalytic activity of TiO2 is dominated by its crystal phase, size, morphology, and surface structure [96–99]. From this point, the different-shaped TMCs are synthesized as shown in Fig. 5(a) [100]. A thin layer of an aqueous solution containing TiF4, NH4NO3, P123, and NH4F was dropped on a silicon wafer and calcined at 500°C. Intermediate NH4TiOF3 crystals were formed in the initial annealing process (<200°C) [8]. During the self-assembly process, the amount of NH4F added was critical in controlling the size and thickness of the crystal [101]. When the molar ratio x of NH4F relative to that of P123 was in the range 0–232, TMC morphology (TMC-1–4 with different {001}/{101} ratios) gradually became thinner and longer from cubic (thickness ∼290nm and average size ∼650nm) to plate-like (thickness ∼120nm and larger size ∼1.4µm) structure. It means the proportion of {001} surfaces increased and that of {101} surfaces decreased due to the oriented crystal growth along the [101] axis (Fig. 5b–e). With increasing annealing temperature, topotactic transformation occurred from NH4TiOF3 to anatase TMCs, leading the formation of superstructures with tunable facet for understanding their fundamental redox catalysis. The systematically mechanistic studies provided a proper understanding of the superior photochemical behavior on exposed facet [102–105]. 4 Topotactic transformation confined doping into TMCs with visible-light activation Extension of the absorption of TiO2 into the visible region is strongly required for effectively utilizing the solar energy with practical functions [22]. From the strategies of mid-gap energy state creation or intrinsic band gap narrowing [23,25], a facile synthesis of doped TMCs with higher visible-light activity was developed. 4.1 N-type F-doping on TMC Aimed at the practical utilization of visible light, a variety of modifications are undertaken to tune the band gap of the electronic structure on TiO2 [106,107]. The oriented transformation of TMCs and its compatibility with n-type F-doping were reported very recently (Fig. 6a) [19]. The intermediate NH4TiOF3 was firstly formed below 200°C after 2–3mm thickness of precursor drop was initial annealed on a silicon wafer [18]. With elevating annealing temperature from 200 to 500°C, the n-type F-doped TMCs was obtained with the coloration from white to pale yellow after topotactic transformation in air, attributed to the isolated color centers in the mid-gap from higher F content. The F-doped TMCs with roughening facet and visible porosity showed good dispersion of F dopant in elemental mapping (Fig. 6b and c). During the topotactic transformation from NH4TiOF3 to TMCs, other intermediates such as HTiOF3 and TiOF2, are actually formed. The oriented transformation of TMCs such as crystal growth, phase transition, and morphologic change was systematically monitored via in situ temperature-dependent techniques for the first time. In situ temperature-dependent powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were carried out to monitor the evolution of phase composition and crystallization during the in situ topotactic F-doping (Fig. 7 a). It was found that the crystallinity of TiO2 (2θ = 25.1°) increased along with the decreases of all diffraction intensities of NH4TiOF3 from T230 to T260. Due to the similar diffraction peaks, the dissolution of NH4TiOF3 to intermediate HTiOF3 was not characterized, but the formation of intermediate HTiOF3 from NH4TiOF3 after NH3 gas removal was further confirmed from X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements. The intermediate TiOF2 with (100) plane diffraction (2θ = 23.4°) was found in T290, which is coincided with thermogravimetry (TG). From the peak deconvolution of XRD pattern obtained from T160 to T320 (Fig. 7b), it was found that NH4TiOF3 (HTiOF3) was changed to TiOF2 by annealing above 200°C. With the disappearance of TiOF2 peaks at ∼300°C, the transformation of TiOF2 to F-doped TiO2 started. The crystallinity of anatase TiO2 was improved by heat treatment at 500°C. The dynamic structural evolution with phase transition in topotactic F-doping was monitored via in situ temperature-dependent TEM (Fig. 8 ). The sheet-like NH4TiOF3 with invisible pore structures was seen in T160. It was found that the symmetrical diffraction spots along the [001] zone-axis was derived from the ordered orthorhombic single crystal orientation. The apparent shapes of the samples, T160–T500, were found to have similar thickness and edge length due to the topotactic transformation from NH4TiOF3 to F-doped TiO2 with similar critical parameters in {001} plane. A series of temporal TEM images with the representative diffraction patterns were obtained to monitor the complex growth processes of temperature-dependent phase transition from the intermediate of NH4TiOF3, HTiOF3, and TiOF2 to F-doped TMCs after fusion and shrink and recrystallization. 4.2 Nitrogen and fluorine with interaction co-doped on TMC The N doping is the most efficient method to create mid-gap state leading to increase of thermal stability and the decrease of recombination centers [16,17,108]. The pyrolysis of Ti-compound containing dopants is proposed as the ideal candidate to acquire doped TiO2 after N and F releasing [60,109–111]. The improved topotactic transformation with dual dopant simultaneously into TMCs from the original precursors was published [18]. With the process similar to before, the phase of NH4TiOF3 with sheet-like structure was firstly formed on silicon wafer at 160°C (Fig. 9 , Process A). Differently, the collected NH4TiOF3 mesocrystal from silicon wafer was transferred and annealed in a narrow neck vessel (Fig. 9, Process B), resulting the topotactic transformation to TMCs. During this step, N and F were released from the crystal lattice of NH4TiOF3 and doped to TMCs simultaneously in a closed system, which was in accordance with the clear shrinks of the crystal lattice [112–114]. 5 Photocatalytic performance on modified and doped TMCs Metal oxides mesocrystals with unique optical properties exhibit structure dependent radiative emission, namely, photoluminescence (PL) [36,38,115]. The focus of preparation and characterization of TMCs are strongly supported the mechanism of anisotropic photogenerated electron flow in the superstructures. TMCs show a broad emission band from surface state around 450–600nm [14,104,116]. By the means of single-molecule or single-particle fluorescence microscopy measurements, Majima group suggested that the photogenerated electrons could preferentially be trapped at the {101} facet predominantly, while holes are located at the {001} facet [14]. The developments of TMCs consisting of different functional composite of CoPi exhibited more efficient performance in photocatalytic water splitting. The charge transfer processes in inhomogeneous structures and environments were explored by single-particle fluorescence imaging techniques with fluorescence probes for screening and optimization of water oxidation catalysts (Fig. 10 a) [117,118]. Compared with the initial fluorescence from adsorbed HPF molecules on the surface (Fig. 10b), it was found the Co species are preferentially deposited near the edge attributed to spatial distribution of fluorescence with higher intensity near the edge than the center (Fig. 10c). From the spectral deconvolution of transient absorption spectrum (1µs) into individual components (Fig. 10d), the absorption intensity of trapped h+ (around 500nm) on CoPi obviously decreases than pure TMC (trapped e− around 500–850nm) [6,119], suggesting photogenerated (free and trapped) h+ is transferred to the CoII or CoIII species on the TiO2 surface resulting a new long-lived component (>10ms) to increase the photocatalytic activity (Fig. 10e) [120]. It has been revealed that anisotropic electron transport significantly retarded the charge recombination in the ordered superstructures than traditional disordered systems (for example, P25). In HER, MoS2/TMC (10wt%) exhibited four times higher activity (0.55mmol/h/g) than nanoparticle-based system of MoS2/P25 (0.14mmol/h/g) as shown in Fig. 11 (a). From the time profiles of absorption probed at 900nm (Fig. 11b), the electrons lifetimes of MoS2/TMC were found to decrease largely to 1.7ps (τ 1, 49%), 33ps (τ 2, 32%), and 780ps (τ 3, 19%) from corresponding lifetimes of 4.8ps (τ 1, 23%), 53ps (τ 2, 41%), and 1070ps (τ 3, 36%) for pure TMCs. Because of efficient interparticle electron transfer along the ordered nanocrystals can enhance the photo (electric) catalytic performance [121–127], the orientation dependence of the effective diffusion coefficient was studied and compared with that of MoS2/P25 (Fig. 11c and d). Using the diffusion coefficient of electrons in TiO2, the mean times around tens of picoseconds for electron diffusion from a nanocrystal (a × c, 21nm× 17nm) to the neighboring MoS2 were consistent with the first (τ 1) and second (τ 2) components in TDR. The required microsecond time scale was reasonable for third component (τ 3) of MoS2/TMC due to charge migration through multiple TiO2 nanocrystals (more than 10 nanocrystals). While, MoS2/P25 exhibited similar decay times to those of pure P25, indicating the short lifetime of electron transfer occurred at the interface between disordered TiO2 and MoS2. Further development of the TMCs with tunable facet (controlled shape and size) is benefit for understanding the structural morphology dependent fundamental redox catalysis. Under UV light irradiation, the degradation efficiency of 4-chlorophenol clearly increased in proportion to the amount of {001} surfaces (Fig. 12 a, red column) attributed to their strong ability to form hydroxyl radicals in this facet [128]. In contrast to oxidative degradation, the photocatalytic reduction of Cr6+ increased in the order of TMC-4 <TMC-3 <TMC-2 <TMC-1 (Fig. 12a, green column). Interestingly, this order was similar to that observed from photocatalytic HER: the activity of HER increased with decreasing {001}/{101} (Fig. 12a, blue column). It was obvious that dye (EY)-sensitized HER on Pt/TMC increased as {001}/{101} decreased (Fig. 12b, pink column) [129]. In the EY-sensitized system (Fig. 12c, purple part), the electrons are delivered by freely diffusing EY•3−, which is generated by electron-transfer reactions between 1,3(EY2−)* and TEOA. The injected electrons are then transferred to Pt nanoparticles deposited on the TMC {101} facets to produce poor H2 due to low concentrations of adsorbed EY. In contrast, Ruthenizer 470 is more efficiently adsorbed on the {001} facets, inducing higher HER related to higher values of {001}/{101} (Fig. 12b, light blue column). The electrons directly injected from the excited Ru can avoid charge recombination with the dye cations remaining on the {001} surface, attributed to electrons efficient migrate across the assembled nanocrystals interface and reach the Pt co-catalyst on the {101} surface. A similar strategy for site-specific modification of sensitizers and co-catalysts was recently used to develop novel plasmonic photocatalysts with efficient charge separation, where Au and Pt nanoparticles were loaded on the {001} and {101} surfaces of TMCs, respectively [14]. The preferable crystal-facet-dependent surface adsorption and charge transfer hold great promise for improving the photocatalytic performance than conventional disordered systems (nanocrystals) in pollutant degradation and HER. In the case of n-type F-doping, the intermediate TiOF2 was incorporated as F color centers to TMCs without any morphological change. F-doped TMC markedly enhanced the photocatalytic efficiency because of their absorption in visible light region [130]. To elucidate the effect of F-doping on activity, T500 with higher activity was annealed in O2 (T500-O2) to lower the F contents and remove oxygen vacancy (V o) [131]. T500-O2 exhibits lower visible-light photocatalytic activity than T500, while more superior activity under UV irradiation. Charge transfer dynamics, which are responsible for the photocatalytic efficiency, were compared by measuring TDR (Fig. 13 a). It was found that the first decay (τ1) within the subpicosecond time scale for T500 was longer than for T500-O2 under 440-nm laser excitation, attributed to their trapping/detrapping processes via Ti3+ (F) doping states in T500 (Fig. 13b, up) [132]. On the other hand, fast decay of T500-O2 was attributed to recombination of electrons at the shallow traps recombined with neighboring holes (Fig. 13b, bottom). Followed the similar second decay (τ2) [132], a little longer lifetime (τ3) in the ns-time range for T500 does not support higher photocatalytic HER than T500-O2, indicating F-doping induced favorable surface potential and hydrophilicity [133]. An opposite observation was seen with decay kinetics under 330-nm laser excitation (Fig. 13a, bottom), which was dominated by the inherent defects for the trapped electrons (Fig. 13b). The comparison of dynamics of charge separation and trapping with photocatalytic efficiency clarify the impact of n-type dopant into TMC inducing faster electronic mobility and favorable modification of surface potential and hydrophilicity. For TMCs with N and F co-doping, the photoreductive efficiency of Cr (VI) to Cr (III) was correlated to the optical absorption dependent on the dopant content, which can be controlled by annealing temperature (Fig. 14 a) [134]. To clarify the effect of F co-doping on the predominant mid-gap of N, the NFT-500 was washed by NaOH (NFT-NaOH) to remove the surface adsorbed F. The degradation of methylene blue (MB) was examined to clarify the interaction between two dopants under visible (420–440nm) or UV light (365nm) irradiation (Fig. 14b) [135]. NFT-500 exhibited the highest degradation efficiency than the pristine TMC and NFT-NaOH under visible light irradiation (pink), because of the different atomic p level [17]. In contrast, the pristine TMC showed the superior efficiency than other two under UV irradiation (gray). From the comparison of charge carrier dynamics in the redox reaction under visible or UV light irradiation (Fig. 14c), it is suggested that the N and F dopants affect the overall reaction efficiency as shown energy diagram (Fig. 14d). After 440-nm laser excitation, electrons in NFT-500 are excited from the mid-gap sate (N 2p) to the conduction band Ti 3d and directly trapped (τ1) by the adjacent Vo (red line in Fig. 14d) [130,136], while the generated holes were separated at the N 2p state. After the electrons equilibrium (τ2), the NFT-500 with a longer lifetime (τ3) was favorable for increasing photocatalytic efficiency. NFT-NaOH with longer lifetimes of two components (τ2, τ3) exhibited the lower efficiency than NFT-500. The shorter lifetime of NFT-NaOH (τ1) corresponds to the Vo at the deep state [130,135]. Under UV laser excitation at 330-nm, the generated electrons and holes on pristine TMC are usually trapped at the surface defects (τ1) to yield reductive oxygen species (Fig. 14d, black line) for photocatalytic efficiency (longer τ2 and τ3) [31]. It can be seen that the slower recombination process on NFT-500 corresponds to the hole localized on the N 2p state (Fig. 14d) [137,138], leading to low yield of hydroxyl radical [139]. Compared with NFT-500, NFT-NaOH exhibited low photocatalytic efficiency even though the longer lifetime due to the effect of hydroxyl radical (OH•) for preferential adsorption of MB (Fig. 14d). 6 Conclusions In the present minireview, we highlighted the development of TMC and clarify their photochemical characteristics from UV light to visible light region after modification or doping. All works help us to gain an in-depth understanding of the efficient charge separation within appropriate morphologies of materials and good structure-induced photocatalytic activity for environmental remediation and energy conversion. With intensive studies of extraordinary performance in TMC, we propose that the following research areas are of great importance to improve the active efficiency and potential application. Using mesocrystals with a high crystallinity and large porosity, it is possible to construct multifunctional narrow band materials (e.g., C3N4, CeO2, BiVO4) for application to heterogeneous (photo) catalysts. In addition, mesocrystals with advantageous electronic conductivity and optoelectronic properties have attracted potential applications in (photo) electronic device, such as anode materials for Li-ion batteries and electrode materials for supercapacitor. Furthermore, mesocrystals with good biocompatibility and stability can be ideal candidates of biomedical materials. Further increasing efforts are necessary for the development of topochemcial techniques to exploit new network semiconductors or Ti-based perovskite oxide semiconductors in versatile solar energy conversion. With respect to unambiguous reaction mechanisms and distinctive internal orientation of various mesocrystals, the development of time- and spatial-resolved measurements (i.e., single-molecule, single-particle fluorescence microscopy and TDR) can open the material optimization and design together with the knowledge of structural and electronic characterization. Since mesocrystals are still at the early stage of the development, the promising future with challenge as the basic building block will be foreseen for next generation of high-end materials in wide application with expected better biomedical, energy and environmental performance. coredata.dc:description: Ordered metal oxides superstructures have attracted much more attention in the fields of fuel generation and environmental purification owing to their unique physiochemical characteristics such as large surface area, fine pore structure, efficient electronic mobility, and good stability. Very recently, TiO2 mesocrystals (TMCs) having superstructures self-assembled by TiO2 nanoparticle building blocks, are of considerable interest in current research and application ranging from UV to visible light attributed to their efficient charge separation and superior photocatalytic activity. In this review, we describe the common procedures to prepare unique TMCs and overview of recent developments of TMCs during last 3years, especially the structure-related or electronic-effected mechanism in photocatalytic reaction. Further, we introduce the characterization and fundamental properties of modified TMCs by the means of single-particle fluorescence microscopy for unraveling the charge transport and photocatalytic properties of individual TMCs and time-resolved diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (TDR) for monitoring the charge transfer dynamics. Finally, various aspects on TMCs are discussed for the future developments of energy and environmental fields.
